intro: Pluchea chapmanii, commonly known as Chapman's groundsel, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive leaf structures. The plant typically has hairy, alternate leaves and produces small yellow flowers that bloom in the summer months. It thrives in dry, rocky habitats and is often found in desert or semi-desert environments. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endangered species in some regions.
